Summary/Todos: Preparing the framework (JS code and build process packaging) for creating apps that run in AIR's: 1. non-application sandbox 2. application sandbox
From recent posts to the mailing list:
Back in July 2007 qooxdoo was one of the first adopters of Adobe AIR, way before its 1.0 was finally released (Feb 2008??). But API progress and security changes require some significant changes to the original code.
Still, it can be done: qooxdoo's build process is able to do all the processing and packaging that is required for a deployable AIR app. While the security restrictions are more difficult to cope with, Adobe did a smart job there, accounting for some alternative scenarios, so it's even possible to run a regular, unmodified qooxdoo app as an AIR app.
An unmodified qooxdoo can't be used for creating apps that run in the application sandbox (e.g. due to the lazy evaluations of dynamic properties after application startup). A non-application sandbox is fine (as explained above), and as Adobe is providing a "bridge", AIR API could selectively be exposed to the qooxdoo app. This is a potential security issue, though, which needs careful inspection and fool-proof wrappers.
I have started some work in this direction but could not yet publish it because of interests of the company I am working for.
Currently, there are no plans to add AIR support.
